titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Long walk to the entrance of Charlottenburg, before dinner.— Couple of hours after at the Casino. M. de Sellentin the Director, introduced himself to me— Finished Lee’s Memoirs. Continue to read Shakespeare in the Evening.

2. Began to read Ségur’s life of Catherine 2.— I suspect it is partial and slanderous.— Settled accounts this morning, as I practice at the beginning of every month— Find them still weigh heavy. Weather beautiful. Walk alone in the forenoon, and with Mrs: A. after dinner.— Evening at home.

3. Another fine Spring like day. Mrs: A. went out in the morning.— Evening at Prince Ferdinands Ball. Conversation with Mr: Caillard & Mr: Garlike.— Caillard says that the Life of Catherine 2. was not written by Ségur, and that it contains many falsehoods.— Did not stay to supper.
4. Morning employed as usual on Sunday’s.— Walk in the Park. An hour this afternoon at the Casino. Reading the monthly review for January which Mr: Garlike lent me.— Shakspeare in the Evening.
5. Letter in the afternoon from Mr: Murray.— Evening at the Princess Henry’s party. Whist with Madame de Castel, Madame de Moltke, and a Russian Officer.— There is to be no party next Monday.

6. Wrote to Mr: Murray. Letters and Papers from America— Evening at Mr: Dorville’s.— Ball there Came home to read my Papers.— Returned to supper.— Home at about eleven.— Conversation with Mr Helbig the saxon Secretary, concerning Russia. The Count Panin now here is son of the General. the Countess a daughter of Wladimir Orloff, the youngest of the five brothers.— Souboff is the great favourite Plato

7. Reading the American Papers.— They give little news.— Wrote again for the spunge— Went to look at some apartments with Mrs: A. and the young Countess Neale; but they will not suit. Afternoon an hour at the Casino— Evening at home, reading Shakspeare.

8. At a morning concert given by Prince Radziwill; from 11 to 3. He has them once a week, being very fond of music, and a good performer himself upon the base-viol, and a good singer. About half the performers were mere amateurs, and the rest professed musicians. The most indifferent performer was Prince Zouboff— The company was not numerous.— Passed the Evening at Doctor Brown’s. Looked over an handsome sett of the plates to Blok’s collection of fishes.— Lord Gower called. He is upon his return home, and leaves Berlin on Sunday.

9. Letter to the Secretary of State— Cannot write so much as I wish. Walk in the park. Afternoon a couple of hours at the Casino. Extract from the Rédacteur.— Evening read Shakspeare. Mrs: A. quite unwell again part of the day.

10. Queen’s birth-day. First Court since her illness and that of the king.— Letter to Mr: King, which I delivered to Lord Gower who goes the day after to-morrow.— At Court, which was uncommonly splendid, and excessively crowded.— The Ladies all in the old fashioned Court dresses, which have hitherto been laid aside.— Read Shakspeare on returning home.
11. After the customary Sunday morning employment, walked in the park.— Finished reading the life of Catherine 2.— Afternoon a short time at the Casino— Shakspeare in the Evening.

12. Began an attempt to acquire the practice of reading German. I continually feel the want of it. But know not how I shall succeed. Study the grammar in the morning.— Writing.— At the Casino in the afternoon and Evening.— Afterwards half an hour at Doctor Brown’s. Lord Gower there. He sets out upon his return this Night. Goes through Brunswick.
13. Letter to Mr: Murray this morning. Continue my hopeless speculation. Short walk before and after dinner. At the Casino— Shakspeare in the Evening.
14. Troubled with the rheumatism. Walk in the morning, and again afternoon— Intended to have gone in the Evening to pay a visit to Madame de Rosenkrantz, which I postponed finding myself unwell.

15. Suffered extremely the whole day with the rheumatism in my right shoulder. Altogether disabled either to write or to go out. Read the report of the Committee of the house of Representatives in Congress, relative to Blount’s impeachment.— Very ill in the afternoon.
16. Sleepless night, suffering with the rheumatism. Second day unable to go out or write.— Spent it in reading Don Quixot. Find myself however better than yesterday.— Mrs: A. also unwell.

17. Mrs: Adams extremely sick almost the whole night through.— Second night without sleep. Find myself however considerably recovered from the rheumatism. Was able to go out and walk half an hour in the morning. Obliged however to return, by the rain.

18. Mrs: A. and myself, both much better— Took a long walk in the morning; but excused ourselves from attending the ball given by the Princess Louis on occasion of the marriage of Mademoiselle de Knobelsdorff, one of her maids of honour.— Continued reading Don Quixot, in Smollett’s translation, which must I think be a good one— His life of Cervantes is entertaining and well written.

19. Went with Mrs: A. to look at two houses in which apartments are to be let, but apprehend neither will suit us.— Dined at Count Zinzendorff’s with a company of about twenty officers. Marshall Möllendorf General Knobelsdorff, the Minister Schrotter, Count Lendorf, the Baron de Reede &c— Mrs: A. and my brother passed the Evening at Dr: Brown’s.— At the Princess Henry’s, but her party is postponed, the Prince being here.— At home reading Don Quixote.— Have commenced again my morning lessons of German.
20. Went this morning to look at another sett of Apartments. Cannot easily find such as will serve. In the afternoon at the Casino.— Wrote Mr: Murray.— Shakspeare: As you like it— Snow’d all day.

21. Walk in the morning; found it very muddy. Remainder of the day at home. These days all resemble one another: Mrs: Adams ill again.— My prophetic heart!— I have no doubt of the cause— The cup of bitterness must be filled to the brim and drank to the dregs.— Finished As you like it, this Evening.
22. Mrs Adams confined all day to her bed.— Dull weather. At the Casino towards Evening. Began All’s Well that ends Well.— Read and wrote as usual.
23. Mrs: A. continues very unwell.— Writing in the morning.— Walk in the Park.— Making slow progress in the acquisition of the German language.— Still reading Don Quixote.

24. Mrs: A. apparently better.— At the Casino in the afternoon. Reading the Esprit des Journaux for the month of February. Shakspeare in the Evening. Mr: Schultz von Ascheraden the Swedish Minister died yesterday morning.
25. Mrs: A. again unwell. Her illness gives me extreme uneasiness. Walk in the Park.— Evening finished All’s well that ends well.
26. The usual round of German, of writing, of walking in the Park, of going to Casino after dinner, and of reading Shakspeare in the Evening.— Taming of the shrew

27. Called upon Mr: Cohen, and agreed to take his apartments, to enter on the 1st: of June, and the rent to commence from the first of July. At 800 current dollars by the year. without furniture. This
rent is very heavy, but I can find no decent and comfortable lodgings upon easier terms. If at the close of the year, I do not keep the house for the remaining quarter of Mr: Cohen’s lease, I am to pay for one half of it.— Walk in the park. The young Countess Neale was here in the afternoon.

28. Mademoiselle Neale and the Miss Brown’s here to tea with Mrs: A. who is apparently recovering, but not well enough to go out. Evening at a Ball and supper at Court.— Came home at about 10. The party given in honour of Prince Henry, who is here upon a visit.— The Ball was splendid— Spoke to the Baron Engestrom, who since the Baron Schultz’s death has the Swedish affairs here in his hands, concerning the proposal for renewing the Treaty, to which I have no answer.— He promised to mention it in his first dispatches.— Tyrith, a little bit of an Englishman, as Lord Elgin called him; Secretary to the Prince of Wales was presented at this Court.— Lord Elgin himself was there, though apparently very ill.
29. Letters this morning from Mr: Murray and Mr: King.— Answered the former. Walk with Mrs: A. and alone. Afternoon at the Casino— In the Evening, finished the taming of the shrew.
30. Returned again to my writing. Continue my study of German.— Walk. In the Evening read part of the Winter’s Tale. Find the rheumatism still a little troublesome.

31. Examining a large catalogue of books soon to be sold; find however scarcely one for which I have occasion. Snow, part of the day, and intercepted part of my usual walk. Finished the Winter’s Tale in the Evening.

Day. Rise usually about seven. Study German two or three hours. Breakfast. dress.— Write untill two P.M. Walk an hour. Dine— Pass an hour at the Casino. Evening till 9. at home reading. Sup. Bed soon after ten.— A regular though dull life.
